Story: Literally the only story you get is a credits scroll at the end. Not even gonna rate.

Graphics: Man
column45: there's some pretty great looking art in this game. The graphics feel like an "HD Genesis/Mega Drive game
column46:
which once again fits perfectly with the Ghouls 'n' Ghosts inspiration. All of the enemy designs are great, there's detail practically oozing out of every pixel laid down, and it still looks great at 1080p. My only gripe with enemy designs are the bosses of level 2 and level 5. They're literally reskins of enemies in the area. All the other bosses are unique designs, but boss 2 and 5 are somewhat disappointing. That's not too big of a deal, though; the core enemy design is great anyways. Of course the game runs well, so there's no worry about not being able to run it. Even though it windows at a relatively low resolution, it fullscreens to match your resolution of choice without a hassle. 5/5.

Sound: I've found that I like a lot of brass and percussion in my orchestration. This game... delivers a LOT of brass and percussion. This makes sense, of course; we're a viking, after all. We don't want a panflute chronicling our journey; no, we want big, bombastic horns, tubas, timpanis... the whole nine yards. Suffice to say, the music in this game is good. Really good. So good that I grabbed the OST literal minutes after I completed the game. There's no voiceacting in this game, so I don't really need to worry about that. I think it's pretty obvious that a 5/5 is in order for this game's sound department.

Overall scores are 10/0/5/5; cumulative score of 10/10. Yeah, this is Game of the Year material. You should probably buy this game before a viking busts down your door and impales you with a flaming spear of awesomeness.

reviewText:
If Ghouls and Ghosts and Actraiser had a baby, and they had a twisted uncle called Donkey Kong Country, then that's where Volgarr came from.

A new game done in the style of old, it really is quite a gem. Simplistic as can be in terms of gameplay, though that is not to say that learning how to control Volgarr is not an obstacle with a nice skill ceiling. Some may consider his controls rather rigid, but if you learn how to use him, he's fluid and most importantly, much like Ghouls and Ghosts, very fair. Remember guys, sometimes you have to jump back a bit before you jump forward to get to where you want to go -- little ghouls and ghosts tip for those not used to this jumping system.

From a level design perspective, I personally quite enjoy both paths of the game. However, I think overall the Valkyrie path has superior level design. The crystal path suffers a bit from too many enemies and not enough platforming, but, that may be your thing. Enemies are in and of themselves obstacles, but the game is at it's best when you have to manage both at the same time. So learn to Volgarr well and experience the bliss of the Valkyrie path.

The soundtrack is pretty good, but not good enough to warrant listening to it beyond your 50th hour of playing -- though I think most won't play it that much, so you're fine!

From a replayability perspective, the game doesn't offer much variety once you complete both paths. There are no alternative ways to play, so, once you've beat it, you can either stop there, or grit your teeth and become the best Volgarr player you can be. As a speedgame, Volgarr is simple, but very skillful and both a joy to play and to watch. It may not look particularly fast"
hoursPlayed: there's always time to save. So if speedrunning is your thing

reviewText:
I enjoy challenging games, especially when they look as pretty as Volgarr. The only problem I have with challenging games in this instance is the very nature of the challenge: trial and error. This is by no means old school platforming, merely a modern take on platforming where fun is replaced with frustration and called a challenge. For an old school game, I have played it about as much as I need to in order to assess what I love and and hate about it.

I love the graphics and the sound, which are top notch, old school throwbacks. The graphics are detailed and thoroughly eye-opening, especially when you're swinging around the fire sword. The sounds that compliment it are simple, catchy tunes with very little in the way of complexity, again allowing you into the world of Volgarr easily and without much trying.

What I hate about this game is the absurd view the developers have of what makes a game challenging. Forcing a player back to the beginning of the level, then making them get back to where they died, travel an extra few feet and die to something else they couldn't possibly anticipate, is frankly insulting. I lost my cool with the first level because the enemies that spawned did so differently from death to death, making my learning of the level impossible. When I finally did get through a difficult wave of enemies and pratfalls, I was faced with an arrow trap that just shot me in the face without me even having time to move out of the way. I dislike games that do away with fun and Volgarr certainly did for me.

For those of you who have the tolerance to sit through death after death, this is a game for you (especially for dark souls players), but if you enjoy a really good platformer, buy some of the mega drive classics and fusion games like risk of rain to get the best out of your money. Volgarr would have been superb if it was anything like the classics it was trying so hard to emulate. Ghouls and ghosts for the new generation? Absolutely no doubt...

reviewText:
This game defines artificial difficulty.

It's undoubtedly gorgeous and makes the player feel bad@$$ when they pull off the right moves, but it's absolutely infuriating at the same time. You keep dying at the same places making the same mistakes, which makes you want to snap your monitor in half. You'd have to play this game to feel it, really; you can find upgrades to make Volgarr take more hits before he dies, but it ends at 3 or 4, and you're just as fragile as your enemies.

Yes, I know it's supposed to be difficult, but it fails at that. It's simply cheap. You have to know exactly where to stand in particular situations, where to throw your spears to make platforms for Volgarr, from where you need to start a jump so as not to overshoot it... The challenge is far ahead of fun in this case, I'd say.

Yes, I did play my share of properly tough games, too.

The only game more unfair than this I can think of is Magicka.

reviewText:
If you are on your way to Valhalla... be sure you have earned your place there.

Volgarr the Viking is a game that seems to have done everything wrong. The checkpoint system - or its near absence - makes you go back to the beggining of the stage each time you die. The challenge lies mostly in fixed patterns, so running the same section over and over to master it is necessary. Air control seems lacking, making even the easiest jumps a potential death trap.  Moreover, the game is short - only 7 levels, if you count in the one awarded to a player beating the hardmode. So many flaws in one game.

You know what? It creates a perfect sidescrolling action game.

Volgarr gives you a challenge to beat the game, and does not care if it's too hard for you. Every time you die near the end of a section knowing that you have to spend next 10 minutes redoing the stage, the game gives you a choice of just quitting it. And you don't, because it has just made it personal. Every time you die to a boss you feel like you should give up - but Volgarr motivates you to just try harder and do better next time. And when you finally beat the stage - I've never played a game that gave me so much satisfaction after that. The game is never unfair. You have a level to complete, that's all. All you can do is to master the controls of the viking and learn the weaknesses of you enemies.

The graphics are great. Volgarr looks like a real badass viking, equipping more and more awesome armor and weapons at every step. The effects of his flame sword attacks are just glorious. The audio is stunning, providing you with top-class effects during combat and amazing sounds congratulating you on completing the challenges. Also, this is the only title with credit screen so good that I don't even think about skipping it at the end of the game. I won't spoil the fun, experience it for yourself.

If you seek for a nice, fair challenge, get Volgarr. If you are an old-time gamer of NES era and want to relive some of the spirit of Castlevania and Ninja Gaiten, get Volgarr. If you are tired of games that hold your hand at every second, get Volgarr. If you want to play a great game, get Volgarr.

And good luck.

reviewText: This game needs an extra difficulty option that adds in more checkpoints. My problem is not that it is hard but that most of the time I spent playing it I am redoing parts of the game I have already figured out. The repetition kills this game. If they even doubled the number of checkpoints I would play through it. This game does not need as many checkpoints as Shovel Knight, but it does need to cut down on the repetition. This is left over game design from the old hardcore side scrollers and it made the games take longer to finish. Challenge was what made those games good, bad check points do not add anything.\n\nFun game but I can't recomend it.

reviewText:
Before reading the below review proper. If you would like a short and blunt summary of what this game is see the following video I did in my series for the final boss. This is the essence of the game once you strip away the fake difficulty, purposefully reimplemented arcade bugs and checkpoint starvation.

http://youtu.be/w7IeweqEFL8

If you really want more than that here is the playlist for the series. Now without further ado here is the original review. My final impressions have not changed after completing the game.


You know. I had almost forgotten why I never really had any nostalgic feelings towards arcade games that inspired this one. What with their stiff controls, sparse checkpoints/continues for more efficient padding and quarter poaching, edge of screen spawning of enemies and other such fake difficulty. It's always nice to have a game come along and remind me. Funny thing is, the edge of screen spawning was actually technically justified at the time due to memory/sprite constraints and the state keeping issues that entailed. Now? Not so much.

If you want a real game that takes the pleasing challenge of arcades but doesn't rely on but teh retro" as an excuse for its shortcomings check out something like They Bleed Pixels. That said though
date: be sure you look at the manual for this. They did a really great job on it making it look like how manuals used to look back when they were interesting and filled with lore (Zelda's manual being the most famous for example).\n\nOh and to answer the question a lot of people may have about this. No. There is no pre-boss checkpoints. You die and you have to do the whole level again. This isn't challenging
recommended: it's padding. Bad padding at that.\n\nAnyway
hoursPlayed: I noticed that the mouthbreather brigade was telling people that they didn't like it because it was challenging and they couldn't win (as well as calling people "kid" when their argument is called out
voteText: proving yet again that they're mostly kids themselves that don't have the slightest clue what these games were about and yet put on a facade of nostalgia)
helpfulPercent: I decided to finish the first world (update: make that the entire game). I'm kind of glad too because it gave me more ammo in the form of this nonsense.\n\nI remember those games too. But you're  deluded if you think that you have the same ability to give these ultimatums that lazy companies who didn't want to do battery backups did in the 80s and 90s. Once again
votesHelpful: this isn't challenging or a homage. It's a fundamental misunderstanding of the difference between features and technical workarounds."

reviewText: Volgarr the Viking has its fun aspects but is at best a mediocre game that should still be classified as beta. While it tries to have a retro feel, it really doesn't. As one who played the old school games since Digger was the ♥♥♥♥, I would say that I can recognise a old school feel of platform gaming. And let me just say, I LOVE platform games. But this doesn't feel at all like one of the classics. In general it feels like a lazy unthought through failed attempt.\n\nThere are several major problems with the game. The first being the clumsy movements. Especially the jump movements are very badly made. It's quite easy to get into a position where you will need to jump to move on, but jumping in any direction will have a very high dead likeliness. There is simply a lack of fine manoeuvring witch make precision" (and really
date: it didn't really have to be that precise) impossible. This has lead to many stupid deaths which didn't really reflect how hard the game is as much as it reflects a badly made game.\n\nBut perhaps the most annoying thing is how often you have to start from the beginning. The game has very accurately been described as a "trial and error" game and it is highly unlikely that you will finish the game in the first few attempts. This would be okay if it didn't mean that you had to restart the game from the very beginning almost every time. Meaning that you waste enormous amounts of time replaying parts that are no longer fun and that you have cleared to perfection dozen of times
recommended: just to get to the part you haven't played before. This is even to the point that when you close the game
hoursPlayed: you have to restart from the beginning again. In the old school platform games there was actually save options
voteText: something that isn't here. And in the games where there weren't save options
helpfulPercent: there was often the option of putting in a code that would bring you to a certain point in the game (a code you got for completing a level).\n\nA game is supposed to be fun and I do think that parts of this game is fun. BUT it is in no way fun having to replay the same part for the million time! That is just stupid
votesHelpful: a waste of time and a waste of money. So please
votesTotal: if you want a nice old school platform game
votesFunny: what about actually playing one of the old school games? Like Duke Nukem 1 and 2

reviewText:
I was really disappointed by this game. At first, I really liked the graphical pixel design as well as the soundtrack, mainly because it's very minimalistic but does not feel like some 8 Bit peeptone concert. Plus it is a game about a Viking, which I personally really enjoy hence there are not many Viking-themed games out there.

BUT! The game is not just horrendously hard, it's unfair. Where games like Dark Souls give you enough time to explore and try some moves etc. here you have almost constantly enemies spawning from everywhere and you cannot see them because you range of view is quite small, therefore you often cannot react fast enough. Addicionally the feeling of the jumping mechanic is really outdated for a 2D sidescroller, meaning once you jumped you cannot change your direction exept you do a double jump. But even jumping onto a little block in your way will be pretty difficult because you jump to far. It's supposed to be like this because it used to be this way in the classical 2D sidescrolling era. But it doesn't make it automaticly a good thing. For me it just feels clunky, difficult to control and overall outdated.

The problem with the difficulty is that you simply have to memorize where and when enemys spawn and when to jump. When I want to play a game, difficult or not, I do NOT want to memorize everything! I just want the opporturnity to play through with my skill, not because I know that I have to jump in 3,4 seconds.

Too bad this game equals difficult with unfairness, at least in my opinion. I get it, there are many gamers who want an expierience like in the classic 80's NES-era platformers, but in my opinion this just doesn't fit today as it did back in the day. Retro gaming in general can be very good and a lot of fun but memorizing whole levels is just a sign for bad leveldesign. It always has at least to be possible to play the game through all by your skill. Due to the design choices overall the game feels kinda dated.

Hence this game really doesn't cost much I still recommend to try it out for yourself and probably you will like it better than me.
voteText: 13 of 27 people (48%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Volgarr is two different games in one.

Played normally, Volgarr feels like a clunky frustration platformer harking back to the old days of Ghouls n Ghosts. Volgarr himself plods along at a decent speed, but is flatly underequipped for most of what the game throws at him. The challenges are simple but Volgarr is simpler. You plod along, hopping about, dying a lot, learning the levels, and generally barely avoiding boredom because nothing in this game is done especially well.

Until...

You find the second game. As you repeat the levels over and over, you start to get a feel for what needs to be done. You'll brush up against that second game a few times before you finally realize what's going on. The levels are actually meticulously designed. If you move quickly, throw spears at the right times, and generally play the game as if you're speedrunning, the levels will come together. Every single stupid thing in the game becomes easily surmountable when you deal with it the second it comes on the screen. Enemies will line up perfectly to be killed with one spear, platforming will go by as quick as Volgarr's lumbering gait takes him...

This is the true Volgarr the Viking. It's not a platformer in the classic since, it's a trial and error speedrunner without the speed. Almost like a rhythm game at times only you can really only find out what the notes are and when by blindly stumbling over them and restarting anew. Since the game's final level can really only be unlocked by beating each level without getting hit and with finding the secret macguffin in each level, this really is what they intended for the game.

It's meticulously designed to foster perfect play while doing next to nothing to teach perfect play. Hell, the game barely teaches you the core mechanics except in one of those passive tutorials that people who watched that one MMX1 video are so fond of.

The problem is... it still doesn't make the game all that good. Any imperfect run just falls back into that first, really boring game (Only now with the knowledge that you are screwed out of anything satisfying knowing what you missed.), and high-end Volgarr play just does not satisfy enough to be worth the trial and error grinding to perfect each level.
voteText: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you want a good challenge them I would recommend this game. Otherwise you're probably going to play for about an hour and then give up on it. I just feel like a game should be more rewarding than this. At least Ghosts N Goblins had cool spells you could unleash when you manage to grab a full set of powerups. Volgarr only manages to give you a triple damage spear with the first power up, and the final power up? A double damage sword. Not sure why the sword would end up being weaker than a powered up spear, but alright.

Another mechanic that's frustrating is the inclusion of all these nice golden items, gems, etc.. But, Sonic the Hedgehog fashion, you lose about 75% of your treasure when you die. I have no idea if you can use your gold to urchase upgrades between levels, but I very much doubt it. It just seems like a pointless and not-very-rewarding mechanic to me.

Another point of confusion is the checkpoints. On the first level you're given one after a very easy area. Then you're given one halfway through the level. You want one before the boss? Nah. Forget about it. There is, of course, a door that closes before you reach the boss. This seems like a mechanic borrowed from the Mega Man series, but makes no sense to have it here without a boss checkpoint. It would have made more sense if extra lives were involved, but instead you have unlimited continues and VERY few checkpoints. I would have preferred an Extra Lives system, having to restart an entire level when you run out of them, and more checkpoints.

It's not all bad though. The combat mechanics and the art style (aside from a few out-of-place goofy looking enemies, like the smiley 'Joker' snakes in Level 1)  are both mostly very cool. It's too bad most players won't get to see all the art the game has to offer.

reviewText: Here's the thing with the golden age of arcade gaming... you could put a coin in to continue in games like Double Dragon, Golen Axe, Conbatribes, Ninja Combat, Bad Dudes, Contra, Final Fight, and Sengoku...  The only platform combat title I remember being so unforgiving as to send players back to the beginning was Shinobi, and nobody played that game in the arcade when they could just play it at home on their new sega system.  This should have a free-play or coin-op mode if it wants to style itself as an arcade game.\n\nEverything in the game seemed to be an exercise in rote learning, which is the sort of thing that I only really enjoy when practicing a musical instrument.   I got my trading cards, and now I'm unstalling.

reviewText: Yes, this game is in fact difficult and I am sitting here admitting I quit. I wimped out and quit. But, I am one of those that feels it is cheaply" or "artificially" difficult rather than a fun challenge of any sort. What ever helps me sleep at night I suppose!\n\nThis game is pure memorization with no forgiveness whatsoever. Perfection or bust. Each hit you take has a devastating affect on your chances of completing a level to the point you may as well reset rather than push on. And with fairly clunky controls this is a recipe for a nightmare. In particular I will whine about the jump mechanics. Sure its subjective but I found the jump control atrocious. I suppose I should say LACK of jump control. You jump straight up and down or a predetermined distance. Timing the double jump adds a hint of control but not enough. This is just one small factor in the overall issue; its a grinding unforgiving challenge
recommended: BUT it just isn't fun during your punishment. I can enjoy a Super Meat Boy
voteText: that endlessly punishes you and makes you try something over and over. But I can't enjoy that beating if it isn't smooth and fun in the meantime. Put a little sugar on my beating.\n\nI forced myself to put in an effort for over an hour because of ego or some other stupid personality defect. But honestly the writing was on the wall five minutes in. I knew this game just wasn't for me and still knew that an hour later. Looks and sounds neat at least. So that's something? I polished off my experience with the game by watching a speedrun and feeling shame about my gaming abilities. With a gruff "I'm too old for this shh" I uninstalled it forever. I'd suggest considering spending money elsewhere."

reviewText:
Volgarr the Viking aims to be an old-school tough-as-nails platformer. Volgarr is a fellow that looks more like a norse barbarian than a viking to me, his jumps are stiff and you're so badass that enemies take 1-3 hits (bosses not included) to kill. These said monsters keep coming up all the time so you better move since they won't run dry. The gameplay reminds a bit of old NES game Trojan in a not so positive way (oh the slow walking, oh the stifness of my actions).

You can hit, jump, point your sword downwards while jumping, do a sort of a double-jump by slashing in mid-air and throw a javelin that also works as a platform for you. You can't change direction or control the jumping much so better not spam it too much.

Then the straight-up bs part:
Volgarr attempts to  be hard. Real hard. IT sure is difficult but the difficulty comes from mistakes you make over and over again while playing the same part until you get it right and move to next nasty room. This TOO is usual, nothing too bad. BUT. Everytime I died I felt that was that something I should've guessed?" or "if the controls were any better this could be easily done". Both of these could be dismissed as a bad player ranting but I've done my share of hard platformers like Ninja Gaiden
recommended:
100% completed Meat Boy and went through Spelunky without serious problems to name a few.

Worst part is that the gameplay feels so clunky that I don't want to get accustomed to it.

Good parts:
-Window closes quite fast when quitting the game."

reviewText: This game captures the amazing nostaligic feeling of feeling absolutely crushed. If you are a very masochistic person who enjoys being repeatedly violated over and over again, I could not recommend this game enough. Volgar the Viking will make you question your life decisions. The control is tight, the level design is compact and intuitive, the enemy design and placement is creative, and Volgar's abilites are interesing and unique. However, a specific mechanic in this game can be either very fun for you or make you want to just uninstall this game and never look back. The fact that you will have to die so many times to learn patterns of enemies, where the pitfals are, how to defeat a certain part. It is an exercise in trial and error. That maybe what you want. But if you are looking at this game as a 'small little challange' then be forwarned, abandon all hope ye who enter here"."

reviewText:
This game really seemed like it was designed by a person who wanted to enjoy it only himself.

reviewText: Avoiding repitition is something I was taught very early in game design. The human brain gets tired of the same stimulus over and over, so especially in this medium, you want to make sure you're constantly presenting the player with new concepts and ideas as time progresses. It's a matter of respecting the player's time, you see. Games like The Binding of Isaac always make you feel like you're getting something for your trouble, and the only reason Super Meat Boy gets away with being Super Meat Boy is because you respawn almost instantly, and the levels are so small to begin with. If you die, they don't make you start the whole world over. The brain trust behind this game didn't understand this.\n\nVolgarr the Viking is the worst, and not for the reasons its creators think it is. I'm bored out of my frigging skull playing this game, because my fault or not, I'm sick of doing the exact same thing over and over. Even games like Devil May Cry manage to be tolerable because the gameplay is so deep that mastering it is the reward in itself, but Volgarr can't even manage that. It feels like nothing worthwhile is waiting for me no matter how far I get, aside from having to put up with more intentionally awful knockback and jump mechanics that make the game far less enjoyable than it should be. Surprise: design concepts abandoned by the rest of the industry over a decade ago aren't relevant in the current landscape anymore. This game was outdated before it was even released, and contrary to popular belief, that's not a good thing.

reviewText: Völgarr the Viking is an epic platforming adventure that will send any 1990's gamer into a fit of sentimentality for their favorite games from ages long past. The story to the game is defined, the game play and controls feel like that of the ancient Genesis console, the graphics are wonderfully illustrative and the difficulty is one that keeps the player coming back for more rather than becoming exhausting.\n\nHowever, this game will only appeal to a certain market of people and those that prefer to advance in their games quickly will lose interest. For the rest of us there are endless hours of game play ahead to be enjoyed and relived. A must play for the hardcore Genesis loving retro gamer.

reviewText:
I played quite a bit of this, so I feel I should leave a review. I believe that there is a very fine line between challenge and tedium. Personally, this game leans a bit too far into the tedium arena. Checkpoints are few and far between, and the enemies and bosses are unforgiving. Your survival depends on your ability to spam the level until you learn what obstacles lie ahead and know how to overcome them. It's all about prediction.
Basically, if you like doing the same levels over and over and over and over and over and over and over until you learn them inside-and-out, this game is for you. If you do not, you will find this game to be the definition of tedium and you will simply not like this game. It was built with the hardcore challenge audience in mind. If you do not consider yourself a member of this audience, do not buy this game because it caters perfectly to them.
Other than that, I feel there are a few areas that just felt cheap.

reviewText: If you're looking for oldschool gaming this title will not let you down. Solid controls, solid mechanics and gameplay, no BS and a great atmosphere will scratch that itch for a good challenge-reward experience. I can think of very little to say in detriment to this title, the best of which maybe a lack of checkpoints and a fairly unintuitive savepoint system (you go left, as indicated by a hint but go figure, it took a while to get how this feature worked properly). Overall this is not a timesink game. I certainly could be if you're into speedruns as it offers the necessary mechanics but aside from that it's a game that you gradually learn and progress through pretty much all based on player skill. Highly reccommended!

reviewText:
CASUAL GAMERS NEED NOT APPLY
If you like being kicked in the balls playing a really difficult game (and we're talking Super Ghouls & Ghosts difficult), then this is the game for you!

No health bar, cumbersome control, lots of cheap hits, and enemies that can move faster than your character are the name of the game here. It is brutally difficult, and I have to say that it isn't to the game's credit.

Retro gamers will be reminded of the game Rastan, in that in both games you control a barbarian-type character who attacks with a sword while (mostly) walking to the right. But whereas Rastan is a game that you can learn from, Volgarr the Viking isn't. This is mostly due to the fact that when you die, you go back to the last checkpoint, and checkpoints in this game are few and far between. Your character starts with a sword for his main attack, a spear for distance attacks and for climbing up walls, and a shield for defense, which can deflect some projectiles and that you lose after taking a single hit. If you're lucky, you can find a treasure chest that will first upgrade your shield (I have no idea what this does because you lose the upgraded shield after one hit -- it doesn't go back to the normal shield, mind you, it just goes away like the regular shield), then upgrade you to a helmet (that will take an additional hit, bringing your hit points up to two, after which you die), and a flaming sword that I presume increases your attacks (I don't know because I lost the flaming sword every single time after I got it on single-hit enemies).

The graphics are pleasant to look at in a 90s arcade sort of way, and the sound is certainly up to par with titles in that vein, but that's about all I can say in its favor.

Now, I'm occasionally up for a side-scrolling platforming challenge: I've beaten Super The Empire Strikes Back on the SNES, every version of Bionic Commando on every system it was ever made for, Strider on the Sega Genesis and quite a few of the NES Mega Man games. Maybe it's my old age setting in, or maybe I'm just tired of developer B.S., but I'm really starting the hate the kind of cheap, artificial challenge some of these modern platformers are offering by making the game so unforgiving. I've played the game for about two hours, and I've only ever gotten to the second checkpoint (not even the end of the first stage, if there are more stages). Oh yeah, and you have to start the game from the beginning every single time you quit the game and restart, so you'd better get good at those first few areas. I was really looking forward to this game and now I'm just angry that I've purchased it.

If masochism and self-mutilation are your thing, then by all means: Go for it! Anyone who just wants to play a fun, challenging platform game can spend their money on Spelunky, Shovel Knight, Axiom Verge, or any of the dozens of other titles on Steam that are more rewarding, more forgiving, and certainly more fun.

reviewText:
Liked the graphics and liked the music...and the screen shots are cool...thought it would be a great 2D side scroller like Zelda 2...but i was mistaken...

It's hard and not the good kind of hard...Ghosts and Goblins kind of hard...it's good if you are a hard core 2D gamer but my days of ghosts and goblins are done.( i bet James Rolf THE AVGN can beat it! )

What bugged me, aside from the long distance between each checkpoint, was the game design decisions! you can't stir yourself mid air, you walk slow and when you try to roll, your character turns around looking the other way and then an enemy will touch you and you will lose armor or die.There is always enemies respawning and lining up behind each other.(I'm sure the developer did that so you can't just bypass enemies and levels ).When you respawn in a check point all your armor upgrades are gone, so if you made it to the check point fully upgraded and then died, when you respawn, you get nothing.If you are near a rope and want to do an air attack the character grabs the rope which in most cases will mean your death or losing armor.BUT atleast there is no timer!

It's not one of those good Retro games like Contra or Zelda 2...it's like i said is a lot like Ghosts and Goblins...it's very punishing rather than rewarding...

reviewText:
CASUAL GAMERS NEED NOT APPLY
If you like being kicked in the balls playing a really difficult game (and we're talking Super Ghouls & Ghosts difficult), then this is the game for you!

No health bar, cumbersome control, lots of cheap hits, and enemies that can move faster than your character are the name of the game here. It is brutally difficult, and I have to say that it isn't to the game's credit.

Retro gamers will be reminded of the game Rastan, in that in both games you control a barbarian-type character who attacks with a sword while (mostly) walking to the right. But whereas Rastan is a game that you can learn from, Volgarr the Viking isn't. This is mostly due to the fact that when you die, you go back to the last checkpoint, and checkpoints in this game are few and far between. Your character starts with a sword for his main attack, a spear for distance attacks and for climbing up walls, and a shield for defense, which can deflect some projectiles and that you lose after taking a single hit. If you're lucky, you can find a treasure chest that will first upgrade your shield (I have no idea what this does because you lose the upgraded shield after one hit -- it doesn't go back to the normal shield, mind you, it just goes away like the regular shield), then upgrade you to a helmet (that will take an additional hit, bringing your hit points up to two, after which you die), and a flaming sword that I presume increases your attacks (I don't know because I lost the flaming sword every single time after I got it on single-hit enemies).

The graphics are pleasant to look at in a 90s arcade sort of way, and the sound is certainly up to par with titles in that vein, but that's about all I can say in its favor.

Now, I'm occasionally up for a side-scrolling platforming challenge: I've beaten Super The Empire Strikes Back on the SNES, every version of Bionic Commando on every system it was ever made for, Strider on the Sega Genesis and quite a few of the NES Mega Man games. Maybe it's my old age setting in, or maybe I'm just tired of developer B.S., but I'm really starting the hate the kind of cheap, artificial challenge some of these modern platformers are offering by making the game so unforgiving. I've played the game for about two hours, and I've only ever gotten to the second checkpoint (not even the end of the first stage, if there are more stages). Oh yeah, and you have to start the game from the beginning every single time you quit the game and restart, so you'd better get good at those first few areas. I was really looking forward to this game and now I'm just angry that I've purchased it.

If masochism and self-mutilation are your thing, then by all means: Go for it! Anyone who just wants to play a fun, challenging platform game can spend their money on Spelunky, Shovel Knight, Axiom Verge, or any of the dozens of other titles on Steam that are more rewarding, more forgiving, and certainly more fun.

reviewText:
Precision action platforming with janky but predictable controls. This is probably something I would have played and gotten into when I was 7 years old, paid for a rental, and didn't have any other choices for games, but at this point the platforming isn't really that rewarding or fun for the number of times you'll die.

Every time you lose you think you have to train yourself to be a better robot, pushing the buttons more precisely at the right times without error. With no additional gameplay mechanics or bells or whistles or draws to the game I can call this a pretty pure example of the realtime precision button pressing" genre. That should be a steam game tag so I know to avoid it in future purchases.

As someone else stated
date: you will either waste a lot of time on this game trying to prove you are hardcore or be done with it in 15 minutes. I can't help but think all the wannabe badasses who love this game are under 21
hoursPlayed: and competing in their own version of an arm wrestling contest with Internet strangers OR are maybe prone to crying out at night "I'm too weak! I'm too weak!" while engaging in self flagellation to toughen themselves (i.e. their fingers) up. I also give this game one finger up."

reviewText: Volgarr the Viking is one of the very best action/platformers ever made so go buy it now.\n\nStill reading instead of adding it to your cart? okay perhaps a bit more convincing is needed for some reason. I agree with those who say it's a bit reductive to compare games to fusions of other well known titles, but here it's perfectly applicable as Volgarr is what you'd get by combining Ghosts & Goblins with FromSoftware's Souls series. The Ghosts & Goblins influence is felt immediately not just by the slower, more deliberate pacing, but also by the nonrefundable jump arc, once you jump you're committed to it with only a double jump to save you from a poorly timed one. At the same time Volgarr conjures the spirirt of the souls series by teaching gamers through death and punishing failure as it's primary tool and while countless games have done the same thing years before any souls game existed Volgarr mirrors the souls games emphasis on combat and environment awareness. Learning each enemy's attack and movement pattern while avoiding stage hazards is the core of the game so if you rush your way through it without being as patient and methodical as the game wants you to be then you're gonna have a bad time". That being said if you accept the fact that you will die a lot and manage to not throw your controller or keyboard through your monitor
date: then eventually some of Volgarr's badassery will transfer to you with that percentage growing as you master the mechanics and start feeling the flow of the game. Each chest adds an extra piece of armor to your arsenal depending on what you already have equipped while getting hit knocks off a piece so don't get hit if you want to keep your gear. No one is scared of a naked viking...my apologies to the naked viking communities of the world
recommended: but c'mon you know a flaming sword and metal shield can't ever hurt...well at least not you!\n\nIf you're sick of the AAA
voteText: hand holding of modern games that think you're incapable of coloring inside the lines then pick up Volgarr the Viking and be reminded that some games still respect your reflexes and intelligence as a gamer."

date: then eventually some of Volgarr's badassery will transfer to you with that percentage growing as you master the mechanics and start feeling the flow of the game. Each chest adds an extra piece of armor to your arsenal depending on what you already have equipped while getting hit knocks off a piece so don't get hit if you want to keep your gear. No one is scared of a naked viking...my apologies to the naked viking communities of the world
recommended: but c'mon you know a flaming sword and metal shield can't ever hurt...well at least not you!\n\nIf you're sick of the AAA
voteText: hand holding of modern games that think you're incapable of coloring inside the lines then pick up Volgarr the Viking and be reminded that some games still respect your reflexes and intelligence as a gamer."

reviewText:
My Terrible, Terrible Review of Volgin the Viking
hardcore 2/2 It's an old school platformer. It's a good one too.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Do you like Ghosts n Goblins/Ghouls n Ghosts?
Do you like Golden Axe/Altered Beast?
Do you like a good, challenging platformer/sidescrolling action game?

If yes to at least 2 out of 3 of those questions, you should try this. If yes to one or none of those questions, you should try this anyways because it may change your answer.

See, what makes this game the best is that it doesn't start in fullscreen, so if you're a man/woman/person/not-person who likes to multitask (aka look up strategy guides), this game's got you covered.

I rate it a softcore 5/5. What the FFFF♥♥♥♥ is a start menu?! Vikings don't need those!

~ Leif Erikson

reviewText:
First impression of a bit of the first level - review to be taken with a grain of salt.

I'm not saying no to this because 'oh it's too hard!' I'm saying no to tihs game because the controls on the first level are lacking. The 3 hit system? Totally fine with it. What I'm not fine with is my character being swarmed by unlimited spawning enemies. That isn't good game design, so I don't get where the praise is coming from. On top of this, you cannot nudge your character when they double jump. There is a section with spikes where you have to push it just right, or have a previous thing to absorb the spike damage. I got it right once, but honestly not liking how the controls feel.

Good call back to the old platformer days, but fails to meet modern standards in terms of combat. Might be up the alleyway of those who enjoyed it though. I just feel the game is making it unecessarily janky on purpose.

reviewText:
Too frustrating.

This is a throw back to old arcade hack and slash games of the 80's and 90's It has a charming art style and great sounds effects and music.  It does a great job of recrating the old arcade feel of that era.  Unfortuanly it also emulates the frustrating diffiuclty of the coin ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s of the time aswell.

The game is way too hard for me to enjoy it.  you can only take a couple of hits before you die. there is only like one check point per level and enmies either infantly spawn or are positioned in such a way as to make things as difficult as possible for you.

I get what the game is going for and i'm sure this kind of game will appeal to certian types of gamers but i personally can't get into this game.  If your after retro i'd recommend Shovel Knight or Shante before giving this a try.

reviewText: I am sorry, I'm just not into this game. I think it is irritating that levels rarely have checkpoints and the only difficulty is aggressively high. Don't think, I'm a casual ♥♥♥♥♥ gamer. I like Demon's Souls and Dark souls and I am a huge fan of Super Meat Boy and Gothic. Volgarr however seems to remaster only the bad things from our NES era. Why do I have to go through half a level (that is already known to me and its walkthrough already goes automatic for me) only to encounter swift difficult moment that I am stuck in and die in few seconds? Why can't I pierce the wall of an enemy with my spear if they are out of the screen? There is a wall just on the next screen. Why is it so hard for a spear to find it? Controls are not as responsive as it is required for some ingame moments. You know, there is a reason why developers abandon these things. I want to be able to practice one difficult moment in the middle of the level only. I want to try different tactics, learn the patterns, but for every try I have to go through a long starting part of the level that I already know. Sine Mora has special mode that allows you to practice boss fights only.  Super Meat boy does not have checkpoints because each level is 30 seconds long (maximum). Volgarr is not that unique for me to be dragged through already experienced gameplay over and over untill some intense moment everytime I die. I am highly disappointed in this game.

reviewText:
This game is not a fun game. Its a boring hard grind from start to finnish. The game tries its hardest to kill you in cheap ways, miss time a jump - dead, swing your weapon at the wrong time - dead, use the downward attack (doesnt work 25% of the time) - dead. Start from the beggining of the level and redo it all without any mistakes. If you get hit once on the way to the boss you may aswel restart. It tries to be hard for the sake of being hard which doesnt lead to an enjoyable experience.

The game pads its length out by making you redo the levels everytime you die, this made sense back when we were all playing megadrive games and you couldnt save progress but this is 2014 and we have moved on from this artificial style of difficuilty. While the majority of games these days are far to easy and hold your hand through everything this game goes the exact opposite way and too far in that direction. Its hard because you have to remmember the location of every enemy and their attack pattern and the exact way to deal with that enemy in that location, the game is basically one long session of memorising trivial details and then carrying out those movements precisely each time.

The game has a certain charm to its style and it can be satisfying when you finnaly defeat that boss you were stuck on. There is pretty much no story, your a viking, go forward and hit things, you pick up gear to take more hits and do more damage, get hit and you lose that gear. It tries to be somewhat of a 2d darksouls, but that game betters it in every concievable way, the game is hard to better portray its story not for the sake of being hard, the combat system far superior etc.

Its a hark back to old style games which is fun for 30 minutes and then you remmember why you dont still play those games.

reviewText: This is a game for people that want to pretend that the impossibly difficult 2d platformers of the early days of gaming were fun or enjoyable. reviewText: This game is extremely overrated. It's not like super meat boy. This game throws false difficulty at you, with no time to adjust or learn how to play in a safe tutorial zone. This game doesn't even give you satisfaction for doing something right. It just makes you scratch your head, and then get angry again when you die in one hit and go all the way back to the beginning. The Game throws you in, expecting you to understand how it works. The Jump mechanics are broken, because you can't move while in the middle of a Jump, unless you take a running jump, or double-jump, which in the segments that require you to jump from pilar to pilar, you LITERALLY HAVE NO ROOM TO DO EITHER, and your Spears are never thrown in the right place to use as platforms. If you're going to buy the game, get it on GOG, so if you hate it like I do, you'll be able to apply for a FULL refund.\nDon't waste your money, time or blood on this Indie garbage. I swear, this game brought my blood to such a boil, I'm pretty sure it evaporated out of my veins.\n3/10

reviewText: This is a fun little throw-back to 16 bit games that were hard-as-nails and required you to memorize enemy patterns to win.  Volgarr the Viking succeeds well at this and there are many speedruns on YouTube that are fun to watch. Unfortunatley this is not necessarily my kind of game though - there is little thought to winning. It is just pure memorization.\n\nIt can be a bit frustrating at times. I hate choosing whether to recommend or not for this particular title, because it is up to your preferences, really. Just know that you are not getting anything fresh here. It is a good reimagining of old-school side scrolling action games.

reviewText: Apparently I have misunderstood the concept of tight controls mentioned often when this game has been discussed, but I don't feel  that having to stop frequently to do ranged attacks, not being able to change your direction mid-air (only when double jumping, how is that logical?) and constantly being knocked back by enemies is in any way a fluent way to control your character. I'd understand if you couldn't change your direction even when double jumping, but the current system does not bode well with my mindset of gaming canon. OFC I understand that knockback is herited from old platformers this game seems to be an homage to, but in my opinion, we could nowadays do well without that relic. Also I dislike the notion that you have to go back so much each time you die, but on the other hand many people might enjoy this challenge and in a way I did expect the game to have such a feature beforehand.

reviewText:
What makes a game great? Difficulty? No. Progression and a sense of overcoming ever increasing challenges? Yes. Perhaps the developer wasn't trying to make a great game, perhaps he was, but bottom line, it's a BAD game.

It's not hard to make a bad game. Consider this; let's take Diablo II, a game heralded as best of its genre even after all these years, could I screw that up? Easily, by tweaking something as simple as drop rates, or damage etc. Just look at Diablo III for proof.

Thankfully, the PC game is a forgiving medium, look at what Aarkalash did, they made their easy mode easy. Volgarr has no different modes, and thus is such a niche game as to be inaccessible to the market. Folks that grew up playing games like Rastan (and still do) would find this offering a waste of time. Rastan is better. Why would I play Volgaar?

Maybe buy this game for 50 cents. Maybe.

reviewText:
Fantastic Game.

Very Castlevania-esque in terms of movement; the game challenges you to look before you leap (probably straight into a pit of fire and snakes), and you will find yourself stopping to assess what your best plan of attack will be. There are a few cool powerups and secrets to help you on your way, and a lot of replayability value.

Pros: Skill-based Combat, Great Theming, Well-designed Levels.
Cons: You will probably die... a lot (but it will almost always be your own fault).

TL;DR Buy it, you dingus.

reviewText: I reccommend this game, but only if you know what you're getting into.  This is a game designed in the style of arcade cabinets and the first few generations of home console games.  It's full of pattern memorization, precise timing, obscure mechanics you need to work out for yourself, and repetition.   I found myself dredging up skills I learned from classic NES games, training muscle memory into my fingers to get past each section.  The one major change from games of that era is infinite lives: No longer do you only have 10, or 3, or even just 1 try to learn and beat an area before you have to start over.  Instead, it breaks it down into well-paced but brutal sections, and death sends you back to the beginning of the section.  (Quitting, however, sends you back to the very beginning, although I'm told there's a warp system).\n\nAll in all, I suggest picking this up, if you're prepared to find yourself immersed in a Nintendo Hard"[tvtropes.org] game
date: something that's exceedingly rare these days."

reviewText:
From the outset I couldn't help but notice the similarities between this and the arcade classic 'Rastan'.  In places, the level design is pretty much a carbon copy.  Volgarr however is a significantly different beast.  The checkpoint restart system and unique moves set give this game an irresistible one more go replay value.  The difficulty level is set just right too.  You will die repeateatedly - very repeatedly - but you'll always know it's your own fault, and with a little practice everything is achievable. This is one of the main things that makes Volgarr so enjoyable.

It's nothing special graphically, but this appears to be the intention.  The game's obviously going for a retro approach to the graphics, and to be honest it benefits from it.  It just wouldn't feel the same with slick, HD visuals.

If you're still not sure, go check it out on YouTube.  If it looks like it appeals to you, you'll love it.
Dark Souls in 2D.

If you are into the Ghost'n Goblins franchise I highly recommend this game!

This is a game that does not hold your hand nor does it feel sorry for you, be prepared for alot of pain'n sufferin!

It is never the games fault if you fail, its all on you. Every enemy and obstacle have a pattern if you fail it, look into it more!

A game for us Masochist Gamers!

This is not a game for everyone. Period end of discussion.

This game toes the line between challenging and unfair, and it does it beautifully. If you play it, you will die, a lot. You will die learning the best ways to combat different enemies, you will die learning to master the jumping for the admittedly simple platforming, you will die learning the level, you will die learning the attack patterns of the bosses.

However, when you vanquish the boss for that first time. When you surpass in five minutes an admittedly short level that before took you forty-five. You will feel like a king.

Its a must-buy if you, like me, love games that provide an incredible (One could almost say unfair) challenge. Otherwise do not bother, it will be a waste of your time.

A perfect game for masochists. Inspired by super-difficult SNES/NES Platformers like Ghouls and Goblins, Volgarr the Viking will make you frustrated, depressed, yet unbelievably satisfied if you beat one of the stupidly difficult stages. I love it :) (I havent made it past the 3rd World yet, but I havent completely given up on it yet)

♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, this game is tougher than a pot of boiled ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s!


BUT IN A GOOD WAY, HONEST!

It truly does live up to the claim of being hard like the games of the past. It's tons of pattern and level memorization, and always remembering what powers are at your disposal.

The game is unforgiving, but does not ONCE treat the player like they're stupid. The game KNOWS you're smart and challenges you to prove it through tough enemy, trap, and obstacle placement. There's tons of trail and error, so be prepared to restart a board many a time until you know it like the back of your hand.

That said though, the boards can be quite lengthy, which makes the fact that you have to clear them on one life a bit of a chore (given you have to restart from the beginning every death). That's one complaint: no mid-way checkpoints. But I suppose that's something modern games have spoiled us with. So not really a complaint, more like a UGHHH MODERN GAMING WHHHY" point.

Although I do have a legitimate complaint: The controls. I've been playing with a 360 pad which is a no brainer for me given this is a side scrolling platform which

reviewText: This game is almost as great as it is manly.  While I get pumped about anything involving Vikings or throwing axes, this game is definitely worth the hype.  Solid gameplay, great soundtrack, appropriately minimalist story, and I just can't get over how smooth everything feels.  The developers obviously spent a lot of time and effort fine-tuning the movement and combat mechanics.  You'll realize that as soon as you start playing.\n\nI highly recommend this game if you enjoy a challenge in the form of a brutal, NES-style beat 'em up.

Imagine Dark Souls as a retro-styled platformer. New players will have a hell of a time adjusting to the game's difficulty curve. Fortunately there are no lives in this game: every death sends you back to the start of the level, pondering on what went wrong in your last attempt. Every death is a learning experience, and if you persist, you'll find a solid, satisfying platformer in Volgarr the Viking.\n\nAlso, flaming swords. What more could you want?

I recommend to anyone who enjoyed altered beast growing up, someone who really enjoys a challenging game, or anyone who loves blasting Amon Amarth whilst drinking mead from a horn shaped cup.

If remembering the term 'Arcade difficulty' brings fond feelings, and you love 16-bit style action platformers, then this is definitely the game for you. While I'm sad to say that Volgarr the Viking is unabashedly and brutally difficult, to the point that you have to beat the game in one sitting; it is a hella enjoyable experience that, seemingly as it should, encourages you to master every aspect of it from the simple and fun controls to the intricately designed levels and enemy placement. In fact, you can 100% completely own any and all mistakes you will make while playing it - I've never said or believed that to have happened in any game I've played before it.\n\nBut once you do... Let's just say that Asgard hath no fury like a rampaging Viking. To boot, I've heard this game was heavily pirated and massively undersold. FIX THAT!! IT'S A GREAT GAME!!

This game really is an ode to the video games of the old days, it even has something akin to wall chicken!  The game is brutally punishing, and very challenging.  But the game is so structured that everytime you die it is your fault, even if it was slipping up for just a moment.  Enemies telegraph their attacks, they are very predictable, bosses have very recognizable patterns, and so on.  You would think this would make the game too easy, but because the game punishes even the slightest of misteps, and checkpoints are far between, you may find it takes a long time to beat this game.  It is a relatively short game, but I would say it has good replay value if you're the kind of person who likes to 100% things, or if you like a challenge, as the game presents a bonus hard path if you manage to max out your power ups without losing them across multiple checkpoints.

My only beef with the game is that there is no saving.  I know it is trying to go for that old game feel, and certainly the original Super Mario didn't let you save your game, but I feel like this only detracts from the game, rather than adds to its charm.  But to each their own, the game is short enough that this isn't a serious problem, and if you managed to beat the first few levels, then you should be able to beat them relatively easily again.

EDIT:  Correction, you can skip worlds you've already completed by going left at the beginning of the level.  This pretty much resolves my only issue with the game!  Please give this excellent game a shot!

I haven't played much but if this were my type of game (as is the case with many friends of mine), I could see it being very fun to attempt to do the same thing but faster, smoother, or more carefully. Again, if you have the patience and like games that you are most likely going to have to keep playing doing the same thing over and over again to progress you will probably like this game.

reviewText: For anyone that was born and bred on coin-op side scrollers I highly recommend this title. Its definitely a knod to the classic Taito game Rastan. Its controls, I feel, can only be played with a pad or old school arcade stick, however. Each section requires you to learn a new technique before advancing inevitably to your death. Its very tight in execution. You will feel frustrated not with the game but with each devicive challenge in your way. I like the visual hitpoint system of each layer of armor and sword upgrade is an additional hit, and the timing for the challenges is enough to encourage repeated attempts. I have a fear however that later levels may be insanely challenging, if so I'll eventually hit my frustration wall and be done with it but here's hoping....

Very enjoyable, challenging old-school game. retro 16 (or 32) bit graphics. tight controls (though not perfect) and an addicting level of difficulty.

My one qualm is that with the game's design, and thats THAT YOU CAN'T SAVE. Spend an hour getting past just the first level? Quit after spending a half hour on level 2? Well, bad news, because you'll have to start straight from the beginning with no saves or continues if you choose to quit the game (which any normal human will do, at some point or another).

That's right, its just like an arcade game-- which is clearly the style this game succeeds at emulating-- no saves or continues once you stop playing. You get checkpoints, 1 per level, whilst you play, but once you quit that's it.

I love the game, I really do, and I was lucky enough to get it on sale for less than $5.00, but I can't help but feel a little ripped off due to this single element of the game.

That being said, some will thrive from the old-school challenge, experiencing deja' vu from the 80's-90's arcade era-- knowing that it's all or nothing. Once you stop playing or run out of quarters, you'll have to try again next time right from the start.

For its challenge, controls, retro appeal, and sheer enjoyability, this game deserves an 8/10. The no-saves feature holds this challenging Castlevania-style game back from being a fully-fledged game. Again, some will really love that, but in these days where time is a constraint for most, its a nuissance.

Remember when games were tough? Return to the Golden Age of arcades with a hardcore action experience that pulls no punches. Volgarr the Viking features simple controls, high challenge, and meticulous design - combined with hand-made pixel animation, an epic soundtrack, and buckets of blood.

At first, I got really mad at this game and I didn't like it, but I kept coming back to it, determined to get better. That's when I realized that I was actually having fun. Sure, it's frustrating. Sure, the learning curve is steep, but when you finally grasp the finer points of the control scheme, completing a level fast can be rewarding. It's not an easy game, but if you're up for a challenge, give it a try.

reviewText:
Volgarr tries to take the gameplay style of older games, but forgets to take the mechanics. Enemies out-pace your swing, and animations are painfully long stun-locks, so you'll frequently be losing health/abilities to animations. If they were consistent, it wouldn't be so bad, but a spear thrown in air is near instant, while a ground spear takes many times longer and locks you into the animation.

As enemies are often above and below you, you might be inclined to attack them - except jumping takes time and will lock your direction, and while you may swing your sword, it attacks forward, not in at any incline, so every jumping guy will get priority for hitting you. As the shield only sometimes is effective (shield direction doesn't change either), a few pixels make the difference between blocking a jumping guy, and getting hit by them. In any case, if you are decently far into a level and lose your shield, it is far more practical just to immediately die and start over, because random control weirdness will kill you. A note on sword-mechanics is you hold your sword straight up, and when you swing, it doesn't go through your front, so if an enemy is up-right you can't hit it, but you can if it is above or in front. At the same time, sometimes when you're done throwing a spear, if you press the sword attack key, you will instead throw another spear, which introduces some of that animation locking when you're not expecting it.

In some vein it tries to take fixed-jumping mechanics, but then your second jump can influence your direction. Inconsistently, as in the first level, jumping against a certain wall can easily launch you over a smalll edge on the second jump straight into spikes.

The look ahead feature" is just a zoom out
date: and overall it feels like the game had good controls at one point (including a wider view)
helpfulPercent: and animation locks to ramp up difficulty
votesHelpful: instead of just letting the game be fun without having to memorize every level or be crippled as soon as you start getting hit.\n\nMake no mistake

reviewText: I've only played this game for a short time but I feel it already becoming one of my favorites. The graphics of course invoke the sixteen bit era but it goes a little deeper than that. The figure it out as you go style of play feels very much like something from a game on the SNES or Sega Genesis. It can be difficult, but not unfair. You will find yourself dying quite often as you figure out how to traverse the game. Every part of the mechanics from the double jump, the spear throw to the ducking roll comes into play without feeling put there in vain. The soundtrack is a more modern score that doesn't seem out of place with the old school graphics. In a world of pixely retro inspired games, Volgarr the Viking actually feels like it would fit right into the SNES or Sega Genesis library without all the short comings of a lot of titles from that time. NOT for players that hate to replay long sections over after death. This game rewards patience. Trying to slash your way to the end of a stage will not get it done here.  Volgarr the Viking is a great old school  hack n slash with modern touches that make it feel even more timeless.
Reminds me a lot of Altered Beast, in a good way. Hard, frustrating, fun as hell; the way I like it.

In short: looks nice, but has really bad controlls, cheap tricks in the overall badly designed levels, dumb enemies and one of the worst saving/checkpoints implementations I have ever seen.

The game looks realy nice, but that's all I kinda liked. The game is tough, but the difficulty does not come from the complexity of the levels or any impossible enemy. No, the levels are fairly simple by design and the enemies are slow and dumb. So, where's the problem. The problem is in the controlls. For example, you cannot change the direction of your jump and that is your biggest enemy, They made some things right in this game, but left many others (I presume intentionally) broken. On top of that they designed the levels to benefit exactly from your impediments which is extremely cheap.

And the worst thing - the dealbreaker - is the save system, or the lack of one such. The game consists of 5 levels (a sixth level and some bonus/secret stuff is also there, but this is the main thing). Each level is split in two parts and has a boss fight at the end. Listen closely! Whenever you die you resurect at the beginning of the part of the level you died in. The second part includes the boss as well. So, given that the bosses are based on patterns (at least those I saw before I abandoned the game) you will need to die at least a few times so you know what to do. Each time you die you must go through the whole second part of the level! You accidently jumped at the wrong direction and cannot turn back mid-jump? Back at the beginning! This accumulates a lot of game time for nothing and this precious game time can be spent in other, more awarding games.

Sadly, I don't recommend this game to anyone except some REALLY hardcore overachieving complitionists. For God's sake, the game has GUI timers for fast runs, as if the game is famous for the skill you can gain...

It's okay, not as good as I was hoping.

Volgarr the Viking is a very deliberately paced linear action-platformer. Think Castlevania 1 or 3.

The distinguishing feature of this game is that it's pretty difficult due to some unusual, unforgiving design choices. For starters, you have no horizontal air control at all, like the old Castlevanias, though you have a double jump. There is also a surprising amount of recovery after landing a jump. In addition, you die after only 1-3 hits, and getting hit causes you to lose an entire tier of power-ups.

The problem I have with the game is that it doesn't seem difficult in a particularly fun way. For example, at the very beginning you're going to die a ton just learning what you can block, enemy behavior, how to space jumps, and how to deal with enemies coming from above and below you. There's no real tutorial level to teach you the basics, which just means you're going to die a lot.

On top of that, the health system is really brutal. The game basically rewards you hugely for playing perfectly by giving you a way better weapon and better defense, but as soon as you take any 1 hit you lose that advantage. It's a weird system, because the game essentially becomes harder the less good you are the game. If you're really good and can play levels perfectly, you'll coast along with a weapon that does double damage with extra range, better blocking, and which is faster, along with the buffer health. If you're imperfect, you have to make do with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ weapons/blocking.

On top of all that, it's a very slow game, that's very low on improvization or surprises. Everything is very predictable, and the game moves at such a deliberate pace that it's principally a memorization/timing challenge.

There are some cool moments in the levels, and the graphics have a really nice aesthetic, but it's just not a very fun game to play. It's very much a game about perfectionism, and it's just not really very fun to learn. I'm actually a big fan of the old, hard platformer castlevanias, and 2d action-platformers in general, but this game is just not a particularly good example of the genre.

Imagine Dark Souls as a retro-styled platformer. New players will have a hell of a time adjusting to the game's difficulty curve. Fortunately there are no lives in this game: every death sends you back to the start of the level, pondering on what went wrong in your last attempt. Every death is a learning experience, and if you persist, you'll find a solid, satisfying platformer in Volgarr the Viking.\n\nAlso, flaming swords. What more could you want?
Even after finishing the game you'll want to test yourself to see how fast you can do it. Has everything you'd want from a retro game.
Only real men should play this nostalgic game.

Good but infuriating controls that always make you die... check.
Monsters who abuse cheap tricks simply to make you yell at them... check.
Level design that will make you question your inteligence even more then your ability to play this game... check.
Retro looking graphics that will take you back to the past to a time where controllers where flying low... check.
Music with a good beat to appease the blood rushing through your veins as you slowly become a viking of olde... check.

Gentlemen... this is a lost classic of the most glorious era of gaming and should have been released in the 90's.

To skip levels, you have to walk left not only at the title screen, but also at the beginning of each level you want to skip.  Also, if you hold the button down to throw a spear, you charge it up and it'll do up to 3x damage (only if you have the hammer shield power-up).  These are things the in-game tutorial didn't tell me, but would've been good to know going in.  Now you know.\n\nThe game is an obvious homage to Rygar, but is much better than it.  It is very difficult, but not in a stupid, cheap kill kinda way.  If you liked Rygar or Ghosts n' Goblins, you'll like this game.

This game is like a love letter to the hardest arcade games of the past.  It's like they combined the best elements of Ghouls & Ghosts with Rastan & made a super tough arcade action platform experience.

Just know that this game is hard.  Really really hard.  After 5 hours I haven't beaten the 2nd level HARD.

~PROS
-Solid Action/Platform Mechanics
-Classic Arcade Style Elements
-Easy to Learn/Hard to Master
-Level Select Feature
-Two Different Adventures

~CONS
-VERY HIGH Difficulty

Just know before you play this game that you will die a lot & you will need to play it a lot in order to get good enough to beat even the first level, then even more for the following levels.  If you've got the time to put in & aquire the neccessary skill to beat the game then you should pick it up.  Even if you don't, you'll still get a kick out of it if you enjoy classic arcade style games.

The game has a lot going for it & a lot of hidden goodies like the level select.  After you beat a level, you can skip it simply by moving left at the beginning of the stage.  Of course, if you want to do the Valkyrie levels you will need to play through the entire game on one life & earn Valkyrie Souls by opening all the chests.

If you're able to get through a level without getting hit & opening all the chests you gain credits that enable you to choose the Valkyrie levels after you beat a stage.  Just know that the Valkyrie stages are much harder than the Viking ones & the Viking ones are already pretty darn hard.

When you go through the game you should take in your surroundings & treat everything like a puzzle because it's pretty much set up to be done a certain way.  If you manage to figure it out you can progress through it with near perfection & not getting hit a single time.

Overall, if you like classic arcade style action platform games then you should get this one.  It's worth every penny & if you can get it on a sale then that's even better.  All the frustration is worth it if you can somehow play through this game to the end.  Heck, I still haven't been able to do it but I'm gonna keep trying.

A tough-but-fair platformer with heavy 16/32-bit influences. The levels are full of hazzards and enemies that will destroy you if you aren't careful, so this is not a game to blaze through; instead, you must take your time and plan your actions. You will die a lot, but there is no life system (unless you attempt the hard endings) so you can take what you've learned and get right back into it. I greatly enjoyed the gameplay, and the music is fantastic.\n\nPiece of advice: open the options menu, go into settings, and activate the look ahead as toggle" option. This allows you to zoom out the screen and keep it that way until you press the zoom button again (space by default). This lets you see further ahead and have more warning from enemies."

This is definitely a game made for a small audience, and I'm super grateful to the developers for making it. You only ever have two weapons: a sword and a throwing spear. The sword can be used in a few ways and upgraded to a fire version (if you're good enough), but the real star of the show is the spear. Not only can it be used to attack enemies from afar (infinitely), but it can also be used to make platforms to stand on by throwing them at walls. And that's not just a fun gimmick... there are numerous chests out of reach through normal means until you find clever ways to throw spears and make paths to them.

That's also how much of the battles unfold. It's not really a good idea to charge ahead and hope for the best so much as learn how enemies attack and make deliberate movements in order to vanquish them. The bosses work the same way too. Believe me, you'll die plenty of times fighting them, but each death helps you learn their pattern and once you know it, you can bring them down without taking a hit. Thank goodness for unlimited lives, eh?

Just in case it isn't hard enough, there's actually a harder alternate version of each stage (with limited lives) that you can only get to by playing the previous stage near-flawlessly. And the only way to get the best ending is to do that for every stage.


If you miss the good ol' days of fair but unrelenting difficulty, pick this sucker up.

If you loved Rastan (or games of the ilk such as Ghost 'n' Goblins / Ghouls 'n' Ghosts), as I do, you'll love Volgarr the Viking.  In other words... it's a fantastic old school, side scrolling, platforming, hack'n'slash!  Superb!

It truly does live up to the claim of being hard like the games of the past. It's tons of pattern and level memorization, and always remembering what powers are at your disposal.

The game is unforgiving, but does not ONCE treat the player like they're stupid. The game KNOWS you're smart and challenges you to prove it through tough enemy, trap, and obstacle placement. There's tons of trail and error, so be prepared to restart a board many a time until you know it like the back of your hand.

That said though, the boards can be quite lengthy, which makes the fact that you have to clear them on one life a bit of a chore (given you have to restart from the beginning every death). That's one complaint: no mid-way checkpoints. But I suppose that's something modern games have spoiled us with. So not really a complaint, more like a UGHHH MODERN GAMING WHHHY" point.

Although I do have a legitimate complaint: The controls. I've been playing with a 360 pad which is a no brainer for me given this is a side scrolling platform which

Very enjoyable, challenging old-school game. retro 16 (or 32) bit graphics. tight controls (though not perfect) and an addicting level of difficulty.

My one qualm is that with the game's design, and thats THAT YOU CAN'T SAVE. Spend an hour getting past just the first level? Quit after spending a half hour on level 2? Well, bad news, because you'll have to start straight from the beginning with no saves or continues if you choose to quit the game (which any normal human will do, at some point or another).

That's right, its just like an arcade game-- which is clearly the style this game succeeds at emulating-- no saves or continues once you stop playing. You get checkpoints, 1 per level, whilst you play, but once you quit that's it.

I love the game, I really do, and I was lucky enough to get it on sale for less than $5.00, but I can't help but feel a little ripped off due to this single element of the game.

That being said, some will thrive from the old-school challenge, experiencing deja' vu from the 80's-90's arcade era-- knowing that it's all or nothing. Once you stop playing or run out of quarters, you'll have to try again next time right from the start.

For its challenge, controls, retro appeal, and sheer enjoyability, this game deserves an 8/10. The no-saves feature holds this challenging Castlevania-style game back from being a fully-fledged game. Again, some will really love that, but in these days where time is a constraint for most, its a nuissance.

Simplistic old-school arcade action with a fair amount of depth, Volgarr the Viking is tons of fun to play and very satisfying when you can complete a level. With no checkpoints and no difficulty settings, this game is quite difficult to even beat a level at first, but once you master the system you will feel like a full-fledged viking. With online leaderboards, many secrets hidden throughout the levels, as well as multiple endings, Volgarr will keep you coming back if you can manage its difficulty.
