reviewText:
It's a Solid, difficult game

The level design is quite excellent, generally letting you see possible threats before it's too late, and requiring full use of your abilities. Every enemy feels different and needs to be aproached differently. The only legitimate issue I have is that the consistancy breaks down after the first level, water switches between instant death and easily navagatable, the enemies move less reliably around ledges, and you get knocked into unrecoverable arcs. But when you manage to pull off the riskier and more awesome attacks you really feel like a viking badass...

...then you get pushed into the sea by a blue fish man that came out of nowhere.

This game has all the difficulty of NES and old arcade games without the loads of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Everything you need to know about gameplay mechanics, enemy behaviors, and other hazards is taught implicitly before you're actually in any danger.

If you like games with a retro feel and dificulty level, Demon's/Dark Souls, Super Meat Boy, Hotline Miami, etc. etc...

...you'll probably like this.

I've finally beaten this f***er!
VOLGARR THE VIKING was probably made to torture people. I mean I literally was close to crying once after the hundredth-retry. I'm not kidding! Volgarr is hard, extremely hard... but not unfair. Every mistake you make is your fault, not the fault of the game. If i had to describe the gameplay of VOLGARR THE VIKING I had to choose this: A combination of CASTELVANIA, GHOULS AND GOBLINS and THE LEGEND OF ZELDA2 THE ADVENTURE OF LINK. Those 3 games combined but ten-times harder. And trust me it's difficult to make a game that is harder than GHOULS AND GOBLINS. Playing Volgarr is kinda like playing memory... on acid. If you would hand me a piece of paper and a pen I could draw a map for all the levels I've beaten, without looking it up. I know every bit of this game by heart and if you play it through you will too! So is Volgarr a good game? YES it is! If you are looking for a challenge, there you have one!

Oh and buy a 2nd controller. You'll break one during your play through I guarantee it!

Volgarr the Viking. A revisit to the types of arcade games from the early 90's that would make you waste all of your quarters without passing the first stage. Here's a tl;dr for those of you who want the basic idea of this game.

Pros:
Tight controls.
Polished, timeless graphics that tend to make you forget you're playing a 16-bit game.

Cons:
Overly artificial difficulty.

The difficulty in this game doesn't warrant praise, in my personal opinion. It feels like the developers thought up a tight platforming world with simple (yet satisfying) puzzles, then completely littered the world with enemies that you have literally no time to react to on your first encounter. You will find yourself repeating the same process time after time, and not really feeling any sense of accomplishment after each time you overcome the poorly designed way they implemented difficulty".

reviewText: For anyone that was born and bred on coin-op side scrollers I highly recommend this title. Its definitely a knod to the classic Taito game Rastan. Its controls, I feel, can only be played with a pad or old school arcade stick, however. Each section requires you to learn a new technique before advancing inevitably to your death. Its very tight in execution. You will feel frustrated not with the game but with each devicive challenge in your way. I like the visual hitpoint system of each layer of armor and sword upgrade is an additional hit, and the timing for the challenges is enough to encourage repeated attempts. I have a fear however that later levels may be insanely challenging, if so I'll eventually hit my frustration wall and be done with it but here's hoping....

Very enjoyable, challenging old-school game. retro 16 (or 32) bit graphics. tight controls (though not perfect) and an addicting level of difficulty.

My one qualm is that with the game's design, and thats THAT YOU CAN'T SAVE. Spend an hour getting past just the first level? Quit after spending a half hour on level 2? Well, bad news, because you'll have to start straight from the beginning with no saves or continues if you choose to quit the game (which any normal human will do, at some point or another).

That's right, its just like an arcade game-- which is clearly the style this game succeeds at emulating-- no saves or continues once you stop playing. You get checkpoints, 1 per level, whilst you play, but once you quit that's it.

I love the game, I really do, and I was lucky enough to get it on sale for less than $5.00, but I can't help but feel a little ripped off due to this single element of the game.

That being said, some will thrive from the old-school challenge, experiencing deja' vu from the 80's-90's arcade era-- knowing that it's all or nothing. Once you stop playing or run out of quarters, you'll have to try again next time right from the start.

For its challenge, controls, retro appeal, and sheer enjoyability, this game deserves an 8/10. The no-saves feature holds this challenging Castlevania-style game back from being a fully-fledged game. Again, some will really love that, but in these days where time is a constraint for most, its a nuissance.

In short: looks nice, but has really bad controlls, cheap tricks in the overall badly designed levels, dumb enemies and one of the worst saving/checkpoints implementations I have ever seen.

The game looks realy nice, but that's all I kinda liked. The game is tough, but the difficulty does not come from the complexity of the levels or any impossible enemy. No, the levels are fairly simple by design and the enemies are slow and dumb. So, where's the problem. The problem is in the controlls. For example, you cannot change the direction of your jump and that is your biggest enemy, They made some things right in this game, but left many others (I presume intentionally) broken. On top of that they designed the levels to benefit exactly from your impediments which is extremely cheap.

And the worst thing - the dealbreaker - is the save system, or the lack of one such. The game consists of 5 levels (a sixth level and some bonus/secret stuff is also there, but this is the main thing). Each level is split in two parts and has a boss fight at the end. Listen closely! Whenever you die you resurect at the beginning of the part of the level you died in. The second part includes the boss as well. So, given that the bosses are based on patterns (at least those I saw before I abandoned the game) you will need to die at least a few times so you know what to do. Each time you die you must go through the whole second part of the level! You accidently jumped at the wrong direction and cannot turn back mid-jump? Back at the beginning! This accumulates a lot of game time for nothing and this precious game time can be spent in other, more awarding games.

Sadly, I don't recommend this game to anyone except some REALLY hardcore overachieving complitionists. For God's sake, the game has GUI timers for fast runs, as if the game is famous for the skill you can gain...

I like the game and most of the gameplay mechanics it involves.

However, everything that I like is shadowed by a huge problem : the jump is bad as hell. I don't know what you guys did with it but it's pretty horrible...
The jump works like this : you can jump one time then jump another time when you're in air - so that's a basic double jump.
However, it doesn't work like a regular double jump... No no, it's like this : say you're going to the right and press jump once, your character will jump to the right. Now if you jump with a direction input while you're in air, your character will keep the same direction, which means that you cannot land precisely where you want...
Yes I know, you can jump once in a direction then jump while in air with no direction input to land below... But to me, that's totally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and it feels like jumping with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ - I thought - and it really seemed - that Volgarr was badass like Ragnar, the ♥♥♥♥ is this ♥♥♥♥ seriously ? :s

TLDR : I hate the jump mechanics, feels like Robocop trying to jump... and for this I cannot recommend this game although I like most of it, god I hate you guys !

This is not a game you play casually to kill a few moments or to sit back and relax with. This is the kind of game that from screen one slaps you in the face and says, I dare you..." This is the kind of game you brag about beating

reviewText:
Summary: A well designed and polished 2D trick platformer for oldschool sensibilities.

This game is difficulty, but its difficulty revolves mostly around learning the mechanics: movement, attack, level hazards and enemy behavior.

The controls are reminiscent of NES Castlevania: in addition to a fixed-arc jump, there's also double spears, rolling and rope climbing. (Thankfully, no stairs!)
Your offensive options consist of a sword and an infinite supply of spears, which can also be used as platforms.

During a first playthrough, you ought to be careful and approach situations slowly, but as you start mastering the game, you'll be able to flow at a satisfying pace through the levels.

Bosses are a matter of memorizing their patterns and finding the safe spots and the opportune times to strike.

There are three ending to get, each requiring more of the player, but not unfairly so.
The two additional endings raise the ante by requiring you to go through alternative stages on a limited supply of lives
date:
which you must earn by traversing the stages near flawlessly.

Recommended controls: gamepad with a good D-pad and at least two buttons (ideally four, for pause and view toggle)
(I played with a sideways Wiimote.)

Pros:
Easy to learn and difficult to master
Tight controls
Well polished
Good replayability, with alternate levels, three endings, and a leaderboard
Most achievements attained naturally while completing all endings
Well optimized. Runs well on humble hardware.
Cons:
No mid-session save feature. (Prevents save-scumming; inconvenient nonetheless.)
Must-do:
Go in the options and set the option use look ahead as a toggle
recommended: otherwise you'll be hitting the look ahead button way too frequently.

Just know before you play this game that you will die a lot & you will need to play it a lot in order to get good enough to beat even the first level, then even more for the following levels.  If you've got the time to put in & aquire the neccessary skill to beat the game then you should pick it up.  Even if you don't, you'll still get a kick out of it if you enjoy classic arcade style games.

The game has a lot going for it & a lot of hidden goodies like the level select.  After you beat a level, you can skip it simply by moving left at the beginning of the stage.  Of course, if you want to do the Valkyrie levels you will need to play through the entire game on one life & earn Valkyrie Souls by opening all the chests.

If you're able to get through a level without getting hit & opening all the chests you gain credits that enable you to choose the Valkyrie levels after you beat a stage.  Just know that the Valkyrie stages are much harder than the Viking ones & the Viking ones are already pretty darn hard.

When you go through the game you should take in your surroundings & treat everything like a puzzle because it's pretty much set up to be done a certain way.  If you manage to figure it out you can progress through it with near perfection & not getting hit a single time.

Overall, if you like classic arcade style action platform games then you should get this one.  It's worth every penny & if you can get it on a sale then that's even better.  All the frustration is worth it if you can somehow play through this game to the end.  Heck, I still haven't been able to do it but I'm gonna keep trying.

6/10

Definitely my favourite platformer. It has tight controls, great enemy, boss and level design. Music gives a good atmosphere which gets you pumped and really puts you in the game.

Controls are spot on, everything is responsive and just feels good. Jumping is quite tricky, no turning mid air except with the second jump, which creates difficulty in jumping if you are too hasty. It's not very hard to learn, atleast from my own experience, but satisfying to pull off well.

Enemies are generally predictable from first sight, but still makes you work them into your muscle memory. They are all fair, and the tough ones are generally first put in a position where you will have an easier time fighting them, and after youve beaten them once they will re-appear later on but in a much trickier spot where it will make you really think more than just using what you learnt from fighting them the first time.

Bosses can be tricky, but very manageable the first time around. They telegraph their attacks clearly and you can adapt to it if you have a good feel for these kinds of games.

The level design is great because it always manages to make you use all of your tools, tricky doublejumps, spear throws and rolls. Not too many instant death pits, instead enemies will be the real threats. Enemy spawns are pretty much always the same, so memorizing them is great fun when youve gotten to the point of nearly speedrunning through levels, trying to get the best ending.

Like mentioned theres also different endings, and by running through the game once the normal way a new player would, you fight your way through the basic maps and get the, well, bad ending. But if you beat a level while not getting hit too many times you will get Warrior spirits that take you to the same themed levels, but with a much harder design. This makes for a great second playthrough attempting to get the best ending by beating all the hard maps.

Volgarr the Viking is a 100% authentic, old-school, hardcore platformer.

If you ever wished to be a 7 foot tall barbaric sword swinger dude trying to get by in his casual daily stroll through the merry lands of GetYourOwnAssHandedToYouPlusInterest on your sega megadrive back in the 90s, then this is the game for you.

May or may not include Dante from Devil May Cry
Meh.

This game is great. It presents itself as an action platformer, but it's more about memorization and puzzle solving. Figure out how to not die at any given second on every screen and the game is a lot of fun.

This game tries to capture the true difficulty of classic arcade platformers. The problem is that the presentation really makes it too frustrating for all but hardcore platformer fans, as there is no real save system (you can reportedly sort of skip already beaten levels, but at a cost), no ability to control the difficulty, a tendency to put you back at the start of a level after you die, and half the levels apparently inaccessible unless you complete every level without really taking damage.

Controls are fairly tight and the graphics and music are good, although in the first couple levels I only encountered the same 5 enemy sprites, 3 of which were basically recolors of the same sprite. I also have to give kudos for a Linux port that runs well, including XBox 360 controller support (even rumble works!).

Still, this game is intentionally at the Ghosts 'n Goblins level of difficulty, with no concessions to casual players (e.g. old guys with rusty platforming skills who don't have lots of time to play). As a result, I can't recommend it to anyone who is not a huge fan of super-challenging platformers.

reviewText:
In short: looks nice, but has really bad controlls, cheap tricks in the overall badly designed levels, dumb enemies and one of the worst saving/checkpoints implementations I have ever seen.

The game looks realy nice, but that's all I kinda liked. The game is tough, but the difficulty does not come from the complexity of the levels or any impossible enemy. No, the levels are fairly simple by design and the enemies are slow and dumb. So, where's the problem. The problem is in the controlls. For example, you cannot change the direction of your jump and that is your biggest enemy, They made some things right in this game, but left many others (I presume intentionally) broken. On top of that they designed the levels to benefit exactly from your impediments which is extremely cheap.

And the worst thing - the dealbreaker - is the save system, or the lack of one such. The game consists of 5 levels (a sixth level and some bonus/secret stuff is also there, but this is the main thing). Each level is split in two parts and has a boss fight at the end. Listen closely! Whenever you die you resurect at the beginning of the part of the level you died in. The second part includes the boss as well. So, given that the bosses are based on patterns (at least those I saw before I abandoned the game) you will need to die at least a few times so you know what to do. Each time you die you must go through the whole second part of the level! You accidently jumped at the wrong direction and cannot turn back mid-jump? Back at the beginning! This accumulates a lot of game time for nothing and this precious game time can be spent in other, more awarding games.

Sadly, I don't recommend this game to anyone except some REALLY hardcore overachieving complitionists. For God's sake, the game has GUI timers for fast runs, as if the game is famous for the skill you can gain...

It's okay, not as good as I was hoping.

Volgarr the Viking is a very deliberately paced linear action-platformer. Think Castlevania 1 or 3.

The distinguishing feature of this game is that it's pretty difficult due to some unusual, unforgiving design choices. For starters, you have no horizontal air control at all, like the old Castlevanias, though you have a double jump. There is also a surprising amount of recovery after landing a jump. In addition, you die after only 1-3 hits, and getting hit causes you to lose an entire tier of power-ups.

The problem I have with the game is that it doesn't seem difficult in a particularly fun way. For example, at the very beginning you're going to die a ton just learning what you can block, enemy behavior, how to space jumps, and how to deal with enemies coming from above and below you. There's no real tutorial level to teach you the basics, which just means you're going to die a lot.

On top of that, the health system is really brutal. The game basically rewards you hugely for playing perfectly by giving you a way better weapon and better defense, but as soon as you take any 1 hit you lose that advantage. It's a weird system, because the game essentially becomes harder the less good you are the game. If you're really good and can play levels perfectly, you'll coast along with a weapon that does double damage with extra range, better blocking, and which is faster, along with the buffer health. If you're imperfect, you have to make do with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ weapons/blocking.

On top of all that, it's a very slow game, that's very low on improvization or surprises. Everything is very predictable, and the game moves at such a deliberate pace that it's principally a memorization/timing challenge.

There are some cool moments in the levels, and the graphics have a really nice aesthetic, but it's just not a very fun game to play. It's very much a game about perfectionism, and it's just not really very fun to learn. I'm actually a big fan of the old, hard platformer castlevanias, and 2d action-platformers in general, but this game is just not a particularly good example of the genre.

spark of sheer brilliance. Developer knows what platforming were used to be about, solid gameplay, little story no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t just you and the challenge of beating the game before you. 9+/10 i'd give 10/10 but some backgrounds are a bit messy in the game however sprite work is great.

And the whole viking theme is cool, too. You play as the ultimate badass. Soundtrack was awesome, especially the credits theme.

To top it all off, there's cool little humors thrown in.

A tough-but-fair platformer with heavy 16/32-bit influences. The levels are full of hazzards and enemies that will destroy you if you aren't careful, so this is not a game to blaze through; instead, you must take your time and plan your actions. You will die a lot, but there is no life system (unless you attempt the hard endings) so you can take what you've learned and get right back into it. I greatly enjoyed the gameplay, and the music is fantastic.\n\nPiece of advice: open the options menu, go into settings, and activate the look ahead as toggle" option. This allows you to zoom out the screen and keep it that way until you press the zoom button again (space by default). This lets you see further ahead and have more warning from enemies."
